subject: Law
title: War Crimes and Accountability
description: A short lesson to help you apply War Crimes and Accountability.

hook.text: Soldiers target a civilian village. Their commander ordered it. Both the soldiers and the commander face prosecution.

buildup.text: War crimes are serious violations of humanitarian law: targeting civilians, torture, and using banned weapons.

discovery.text: Command responsibility means leaders are liable if they knew or should have known about crimes and failed to stop them.

twist.text: 'Following orders' is not a defense. The Nuremberg trials established this principle after World War II.

climax.text: National courts, the ICC, and special tribunals all have jurisdiction over war crimes. Multiple paths to justice exist.

punchline.text: War doesn't suspend the law. Crimes in conflict are still crimes.

quiz.question: Is 'following orders' a valid defense against war crime charges?
options: No, the Nuremberg principle rejects it
